hero.name: Marwan Ahmed Awny Elagha
hero.title: Candidate of the Arab Republic of Egypt for the Arab Scout Committee – Youth Advisors

cv.title: About Me
cv.content:
Marwan is an Egyptian legal professional with published work in International Law and Middle East Studies. He currently practices law in Egypt with ADSERO Ragy Soliman & Partners (Technology, Media, and Telecommunications practice group). He has over three years of experience providing consultancy to the Egyptian Government and the Arab Scout Region on matters of international law, public policy, and youth diplomacy, qualifying him to offer effective advice to the Arab Scout Committee and the Arab National Scout Organizations.

Marwan has been dedicated to the Scout Movement since 2008, starting as a Cub Scout with the esteemed Elsalam Scout Groups. He has represented Egypt and the Arab Scout Region at dozens of international and regional events, including the 43rd World Scout Conference, the 24th World Scout Jamboree (USA), the 30th Arab Scout Jamboree, the Kandersteg International Scout Centre's Centenary in Switzerland, and the tenth anniversary celebration of Messengers of Peace in Saudi Arabia. His involvement also extends to the Arab Scout Forum for Young Media Professionals and JOTA-JOTI from 2010 to 2025.

He is a recipient of the Lord Baden-Powell Fellowship from the World Scout Foundation, the Messengers of Peace Heroes Award from the World Organization of the Scout Movement (presented at the 73rd UN General Assembly in New York), and the World Scout Environment Badge. From Egypt, he holds the 2nd Class Courage Order, the General Service Order, the Volunteering Order, and the Badge of Merits, in addition to being named the Outstanding Student at the Egyptian University level (2023/2024). Marwan is also a member of the KISC General Assembly in Switzerland, the Egyptian Red Crescent, and serves as the President of the Rotaract El Tahrir Club (Rotary Egypt, 2025/2026). He is a founding member of the Egyptian Scout Archive since 2020 and a co-author of a published work on the history of Egyptian Scouting philatelic stamps.

scoutMovement.title: Scout Movement in Egypt
scoutMovement.content:
The Scouting Movement in Egypt is one of the oldest scouting movements in the world, and since its inception, it has played a prominent national and educational role in Egyptian society.

The idea first emerged in Egypt in the early twentieth century, shortly after Lord Baden-Powell founded the World Scouting Movement in England in 1907. It did not take long for the concept to spread to Egypt via foreign schools, missions, and European communities. The Egyptians soon embraced it with great enthusiasm.

Some scout troops were informally formed in schools, first in Alexandria and then in Cairo, around 1914, despite the opposition of the British occupation. Perhaps the most notable manifestation of this opposition was the attempt to exile and deport several of the early Egyptian scout leaders.

After World War I in 1918, the movement rapidly expanded in both public and private schools. One of its most prominent supporters at the time was His Majesty King Fuad I, who saw it as a means of raising the youth with discipline, order, and patriotism. Consequently, he ordered its incorporation under the wing of the Ministry of Education (Ministry of Knowledge).

Egyptian Scouting soon flourished and became an integral part of public life, participating in national events, royal processions, and official celebrations. It also played a significant role in supporting the 1919 Revolution by organizing supplies, relaying messages, and assisting the wounded, thus solidifying its image as a national movement rather than merely a youth activity.

The first official scouting association, the Egyptian Scout Association (Gam'eyet El-Kashafa El-Masreya), was formally established in 1920 to be the organizing body for the movement in the country. It quickly organized major events, the most notable of which was inviting Lord Baden-Powell to visit Egypt in a grand scout festival in 1921. The Association joined the World Organization of the Scout Movement (WOSM) in 1922 after receiving international recognition, making Egypt one of the first Arab nations to officially join the global movement.

In the period before the July 1952 Revolution, Egyptian Scouting enjoyed the patronage of the Royal Family (the Muhammad Ali Dynasty), as it was considered a tool for instilling loyalty and national belonging in the youth. Key expressions of this patronage included the investiture of His Royal Highness Prince Farouk as Chief Scout, Her Majesty Queen Farida as Chief Guide, and Princess Ferial as Chief Cub/Brownie (Zahra). Scouting was also a permanent guest at most royal celebrations.

Following the July 1952 Revolution, the movement was reorganized, initiating a new phase of expansion and institutional framing. This led to the creation of the current associations in 1954: the Scouts (Boys), Sea Scouts, Air Scouts, and Girl Guides. In the same year, Egypt was a founding member of the Arab Scout Organization, playing a pioneering role in spreading the scouting movement throughout the Arab world.

Egyptian Scouts have participated in numerous national events, such as the war effort, blood donation campaigns, and literacy and environmental service projects. Its leadership continues to this day, as its hosting of the World Scout Conference in 2024 confirms its leading position in the global scouting arena, more than 110 years after its establishment.

Today, Egyptian Scouting represents a living heritage that combines authenticity and renewal, continuing its mission to educate generations on the values of belonging, discipline, and community service. Egypt is also rich in a venerable scouting heritage of documents, photos, and symbols that chronicle a long journey of contribution and impact, which the Egyptian Scout Archive—the largest scout archive in the Arab world—is working to preserve and document for future generations. I am proud to be one of its founders.
